pages.text: To get started with anything Create, you'll first have to be able to make $(thing)mechanical power/$.$(p)Early on, you can:$(li)Use your $(bold)water/$ pool to power simple $(item)water wheels/$!$(li)Let the $(bold)wind/$ move your $(item)windmills/$! Quite powerful!$(li)The $(bold)updraft/$ created by $(item)campfires/$ can be harnessed$(br)by $(item)encased fans/$!

While it's technically possible to manually power machines with $(item)hand cranks/$, you're going to give yourself much more work than needed. $(bold)Automate!/$$(p)Note that you can invert the orientation of pretty much any directional Create block by sneaking as you place it.$(p)$(italic)Water, wind, fire, steam. Long ago, the four sources of powers lived in harmony, .../$ Wait, wrong franchise.

Using a single water source block to wrap around a $(item)water wheel/$ causes it to rotate, creating rotational energy.$(p)One can easily stack this setup horizontally, increasing the power output linearly.
A $(item)soul sand/$ block increases the efficiency slightly.

With a $(item)bearing/$ and a whole bunch of $(item)sail frames/$ you can start generating power from the wind.$(p)Spanning $(item)wool/$ from your first $(l:overworld/02_birch_forest)neighboring island/$ over these improves the efficiency!
Just two stacks of $(item)sails/$ will max out your windmill.

Likely not the best choice due to the cost of 4 $(item)zinc ingots/$ each, a redstone-powered $(item)fan/$ can still harness the updraft created by heat sources like $(item)campfires/$, generating a small amount of power.$(br)Better use it for $(l:basics/05_fan_crafting)crafting/$.
To redstone-power it, an $(item)analog lever/$ will work, too.
